content.description: Nice climbing up a thin crack that comes and goes.
content.protection: Bolts.  This route was originally conceived as a traditionally protected line, but there was only one good gear placement on the pitch.
content.location: To the left of the splitter cracks, there is an incipient crack with bolts.

content.description: This route starts off with the crux, which currently feels like 5.10a. Climb atop the pedestal and bear toward the large tree above - anchor is to the left. As the route cleans up, the grade could ease slightly.
content.protection: Single rack .4-3. There is good gear available throughout.
content.location: The far right crack on the wall.

content.description: A crack within a dihedral that starts as an off width near the ground and narrows to fists and hands. Ample face holds are available. This leads to the ledge shared with the adjacent 10a and continues up a hand crack to 5 easy and finishes at the common anchor at the big tree on top.
content.protection: Single rack to BD 4 is sufficient, but a BD 5 and/or an additional 4 would be handy for the start.
content.location: This crack faces south and is located in between the 5.8 Left and the 10a.

content.description: There are 2 cracks rated 5.8 here, this is the left of the two. There are two cracks along this route including an off width and a fist crack. These lead to a manageable roof and then to the same ledge and finish as the adjacent 5.7.
content.protection:
BD single rack .4 through 4. If using the off width for protection, it takes a BD 5 and 6 perfectly.

This route is prone to significant rope drag. Take appropriate measures or the top half of the route will be most unpleasant.
content.location: From the parking area near Little Matterhorn, it is about a 2 minute approach. Go past the port-a-john and head north, keeping left. There is a short grassy trail to the left of the boulder that leads to this area. A cairn is near the base of the boulder as well. Small, coin-sized metal placards read the grade of the routes. The basic shape of this area is that of a dihedral.

content.description: This tips/fingers crack leads to a ledge on climbers right. Continue up, basically climbers left, towards the big tree. The upper section and anchor are shared with the adjacent 5.8's and 10a.
content.location: From the parking area near Little Matterhorn, it is about a 2 minute approach. Go past the port-a-john and head north, keeping left. There is a short grassy trail to the left of the boulder that leads to this area. A cairn is near the base of the boulder as well. Small, coin-sized metal placards read the grade of the routes. The basic shape of this area is that of a dihedral. The 5.7 faces east and is adjacent to, and climbers right of Virgin Crack.

content.description: A short route with fun face climbing. A mix of crimps and jugs w good feet.
content.protection: 3 bolts to roof with dangling SS anchor.
content.location: Just to the left of Virgin Crack. There is both a 10a metal placard and an 11b placard at the base of the route. I presume the 11b represents the route if continued beyond the roof SS anchor, as additional bolts are seen there.
